pageContext.title: Customer acquisition costs are rising. Here’s how online stores can deal with it
pageContext.content:
Photo credit: Stanisic Vladimir

Five to 10 years ago, people thought that digital-native brands and ecommerce retailers had a distinct cost advantage because they didn’t have to pay for physical infrastructure (e.g. storefronts with long-term leases).

But that’s not the case anymore.

Now, I believe that digital-native brands should actually develop a holistic strategy across offline/physical retail, brand marketing, and performance marketing earlier in their lifecycle.

The cost advantage of digital-only companies

To understand the historical argument around the digital-only cost advantage, let’s put rent (and cost of staff) alongside traditionally defined marketing costs when considering true customer acquisition costs (CAC).

(Note: For simplicity, I focused on new customer acquisition vs considering LTV through repeat purchases.)

Digital-native brands usually start with a very small performance marketing budget (D) that can be scaled nimbly, instead of high rent and retail staff costs (B) which are hard to flex incrementally.

Since D can be targeted, it’s usually a better bargain than B. However, with more and more emerging brands and startups chasing after the same inventory in D, basic supply and demand (and users’ limited attention span) are driving up everyone’s unit costs.

This is why some people have been saying that “CAC is the new rent.” What used to feel like efficient performance marketing dollars has increasingly felt like blocks of cash that you throw at various channels and hope for the best.

A new approach

Even when you’re still a relatively young brand, think about your marketing channel mix including offline/brand marketing-type channels as well as physical retail.

This is easier said than done.

The beauty of D (and to a lesser degree C) is that you need to commit very little. Low on cash? Just turn off some Instagram ads tomorrow. Flexibility and optionality are valuable, especially when you’re a young company with an uncertain future.

Below are a few considerations on how to put this to practice:

1. Be deliberate about the right “channel mix”

Each channel has its unique strength around communicating your brand/product value proposition. Be purposeful on what you’d like to get across, where, and how.

For example, physical retail has a unique advantage in creating a brand experience and showcasing the experiential/emotional attributes of a product that are otherwise hard to convey digitally.

2. Go where your customers are

Segment your addressable market and try to get a good understanding of what channel(s) are most effective in reaching a given sub-segment/demographic.

For example, it might be most efficient to reach 25-year-olds living in New York city on Instagram and 40-year-old moms near their go-to grocery stores.

3. Consider it a “point solution” and go as asset-light as possible

Unlike performance marketing, physical retail isn’t as scalable and requires real commitment. So, you need to deploy your resources efficiently—only in places you need it the most and reinforce key regions/demographics.

Given the maturity of ecommerce transactions, your physical footprint should really focus on helping customers evaluate a purchase decision (vs fulfilling it). For example, you could have inventory-less showrooms or a space that focuses on brand experiences that are hard to convey online.

This approach allows you to establish a physical presence and use your capital more efficiently.

4. Stage it, but consider the holistic picture early

Performance marketing is the easiest to start even if you have very little capital, so every startup tends to start there. It’s like a drug that you can’t quit, which is why most companies spend a long time focusing on these channels.

As much as you can, start experimenting with offline/brand marketing channels and physical retail. Every company is different, so it’s critical to understand how these different channels can work for you.

***

I’m not advocating for physical retail for every company out there. What I am advocating is a company that encourages a holistic consideration of marketing channels, including a physical footprint.

This article was first published on Better Everyday.
